frameDefinitions: A Figure is characterized as near the Ground, according to some contextually given scale.
In this frame a Preventing_cause interferes with the ability of a Protagonist to complete an intended Action.
A Defender responds to an Assailant's attack on a Victim by directly, and usually violently, countering it.

This frame consists of words that describe a hostile encounter between opposing forces (Side_1 and Side_2, collectively conceptualizable as Sides) over a disputed Issue and/or in order to reach a specific  Purpose. '' 'He still wants to fight Mike Tyson in about 8 months.'
The words in this frame describe a period of time, as opposed to a point in time.
An Agent is responsible for having intentionally performed an Act or for being the or a primary instigator behind the Act.
frameExamples: She put her shoes <t>under</t> the table .
Samantha stalwartly <t>defended</t> the gateway from the wraiths, crouching low over Stephen's prone form.
He still wants to <t>fight</t> Mike Tyson in about 8 months.
The best <t>time</t> of year for planting tends to be fairly regular.
It has been determined that a relatively unknown terrorist group is <t>responsible</t> for the recent attacks.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Ground</fen> serves as a basis for describing the location of the <fen>Figure</fen>.
The <fen>Figure</fen> is perceived as located relative to a certain <fen>Ground</fen> location. The figure can be an entity or an event.
The period of time during which the locative relation between <fen>Figure</fen> and <fen>Ground</fen> obtains.
The <fen>Preventing_cause</fen> is the agent or force who keeps the <fen>Protagonist</fen> from completing her or his planned <fen>Action</fen>.
The <fen>Protagonist</fen> is the individual or group of individuals who have a planned <fen>Action</fen> which is prevented by the <fen>Preventing_cause</fen>
The <fen>Action</fen> is the action or event certain individuals desire to bring about which is prevented by the <fen>Preventing_cause</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the thwarting occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the thwarting occurs.
This role is the being or entity that responds forcefully to the <fen>Assailant</fen>'s attack.
The person (or other self-directed entity) that is attempting physical harm to the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The individual or entity that is under attack from the <fen>Assailant</fen> .
This role identifies the time when the Defender takes forceful action against the Assailant.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Defender</fen> defends the <fen>Victim</fen> from the <fen>Assailant</fen>.
One of two participants in a hostile encounter.
One of two participants in a hostile encounter, usually the second mentioned.
The jointly expressed sides in a hostile encounter.
An unresolved question over which the two sides of a hostile encounter are in disagreement.

The desired result of the outcome of the hostile encounter for the <fen>Side_1</fen> or for all the <fen>Sides</fen> collectively.  It may either directly refer to the state of affairs that is desired, e.g.
The <fex name='Time'>Time</fex> at which the hostile encounter occurs.
The location at which the hostile encounter takes place.
A quantity or other characterization of the <fen>State</fen>'s duration.  In this frame, the duration can be inexact.
An ongoing state whose duration can be measured.
This role identifies the <fen>Act</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> performs intentionally.
The <fen>Agent</fen> performs the intentional act.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Agent</fen> acts intentionally.
This role identifies the place where the intentional act occurs.
listRoleExamples: The cat is next to <fex>the mat</fex>.
<fex>The cat</fex> is next to the mat.
He was by the park <fex>on Friday</fex>.
While <fex>the U.S.'s</fex> battle with terrorist-harboring nations is far off ...
While the U.S.'s battle <fex>with terrorist-harboring nations</fex> is far off ...
<fex>They</fex> fought over the right to own land.
They had a dust-up <fex>over who was prettier</fex> .
He dueled with his former second <fex>to defend the honour of the man he had killed</fex> .
Following the battle of Naseby <fex>in 1645</fex> he died.
<fex>He was a great actor</fex> in his time.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: The Beginner's Guide to K-1When the Champion Refuse to Fight the Next Title Contender
